Award.AwardTitle: Electronic transport in DNA-based single molecular devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to create DNA single molecule junction devices and measure their electromechanical properties under precise controls of a number of variables applying the recent developed single molecule molecular transport junction (MTJ) system. In combination of theory computation and modeling, this project will elucidate the intrinsic transport mechanisms of molecular structure-dependent conductance behaviors and gleaning important conclusions regarding the enhancement and tuning of charge transport in single DNA junction devices.

The intellectual merit is to develop a comprehensive approach that utilizes electrical engineering, chemistry and physics in the development of DNA single molecule junction devices and control and measure the variables, including DNA-electrode contact and a rich variety of structures of DNA caused by bending, orientations and water and counterions conditions, at the single molecular level. AFM nanolithography and modified SPM-based MTJ technique will enable a new measurement approach. The proposed work is expected to gain a detailed and in-depth understanding of electronic transport in DNA single molecule junctions and provide a major step towards the incorporation of DNA molecules as functional elements in electronic devices.

The broader impacts are the participation of undergraduate, minority, and high school students to research opportunities in the emerging interdisciplinary fields through various recruiting programs to train the next generation scientists and engineers. The measurement and understanding of electronic transport through single DNA molecular devices under the native physiological conditions relevant to the damage and mutation in DNA will have applications ranging from electronic, biomedical, environmental to human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Along with recent announcement of the death of the famous Moore’s Law, alternative science to break the limitation of using conventional silicon-based material is lifted to the top priority. Molecular electronics aims at developing molecular devices that will complement – and eventually even supersede – current semiconductor-based technologies. After 40 years’ research, molecular electronics, has been proven to be one of the excellent alternatives. Among many molecules, DNA, the repository of genetic information, is considered a leading candidate in building molecular electronic devices because not only its π-π stacking electronic structure serve as good charge transport medium, but also it can be tuned in many ways to achieve different molecular conformations, which renders it ideal both as template for assembling nanocircuits and as an element of such circuits itself. However, little information has been reported on measuring the charge transfer in DNA under control of various variables because the lack of suitable techniques and instrumentation. The project  tackles these challenges by applying our recent development of single molecule molecular transport junction (MTJ) system to measure the conductance and force under precise controls of the variables mentioned above so as to gain a detailed and in-depth understanding of electronic transport in DNA single molecule junctions.

 

In the four years (including a 4th year NCE) of the project, Our results obtained from this award underscore the importance of probing electron transport in DNA-based molecular electronic devices. Our work on developing a highly-integrated SPM-based experimental platform and more advanced data processing algorithms demonstrates that the detailed electron transport properties of single-molecule junction devices hidden in the experimental data can be unraveled. This platform is also the technical support to tackle problems associated with electron transport through DNA molecular devices. Our work on studying structure-dependence of DNA conductance and the subsequence construction of the first DNA-based molecular rectifier has further suggested DNA molecular structure modification a rather promising route for the design and fabrication of DNA-based functional molecular devices, and meanwhile emphasized the need for finer experimental modulations and controls in order to both gain deeper insight into the determining factor of DNA electron transport and achieve better device performance. Also, our work on modulating symmetric π-conjugated molecules toward molecular rectifier and NDR devices provided possible modification methods that could transform a symmetric DNA duplex into functional molecular device. Work under this grant also contributed to 20 journal articles and several additional papers either have been submitted or are near submission. Many of the published papers have appeared in top-tier journals, such as Nat. Chem.,and J. Am. Chem. Soc. One recently published paper in Nat. Chem. particularly pertinent to the proposed study, was ranked 2nd of the 70 tracked articles of a similar age and was selected to be top 10 most read article in Nature Chemistry, and it also has been featured in over 60 media news (including the NSF news) and highlights worldwide in the fashion of headlines, “Researchers made the world’s smallest diode out of DNA”.

 

The fundamental understanding we have gained in the past 4 years with electron transport in DNA-based single molecular devices has not only disclosed new insights into structure-dependent transport of DNA molecules as described below, but also led to improvements in detailed experimental controls and modulations of single-molecule junction devices, and more importantly, the creation of the first DNA-based molecular rectifier. Probing electron transport through DNA molecules in different conformations will impact other related fields, such as DNA damage and repair, oxidation, DNA-small molecule interaction, bio/nano interfaces and DNA self-assembled nanostructures. The education, collaboration, and outreach of the PI has provided participants at undergraduate and graduate level the opportunities not only to learn new cutting-edge science and develop key technologies, but also build networks of collaborators and acquire the necessary key skills to work in an interdisciplinary environment. Funds from this proposal have also supported or partly supported the work of 2 postdoc fellow, 6 grad students (including 3 women), and 4 undergrad students (including 2 women).
